attributes.comment:
As I was paying my way through college, many people asked me why I did not
register to vote. I informed them that I was not a citizen of this country therefore
could not vote. The next question that came out of their mouth was always the
same. Why don't you become a citizen? I was always had to tell them, I could not
afford it. At the time, I believe the fee was approx. $300. With $300 I could buy a
textbook, maybe two if I was lucky. Becoming a citizen was not a fiancial priority.
When I finally graduated, the naturalization process moved to the top of my list. It
still took me over 18 months after my graduation to save up the $450 dollars
needed for the application fee, not to mention the $70 fingerprinting fee. When you
have a college degree and are only making $11 dollars per hour, $520 dollars is a
lot of money. So I know you will be suprised to know that I support the decision to
increase the fees.

I feel that those who truly have a desire to become legal residents or citizens of
this country will pay any price necessary. That includes fees, lawyers, fines,
whatever the amount. These people left their home country in order to make their
lives as well as their families lives better. One way to make it better is to become
legal residents or citizens of this country. If you ever pick up newspapers
dedicated to the immigrant communities in this country, you will see that these
immigrants are always looking for news from the USCIS. Although they may
initially complain, all will do anything possible even if it means saving for months
like I did.

Also, I wanted to address the issue if you bring back laws such as 245i, that will
also add income to the USCIS. Think about how many people would benefit under
the reimplementation of such laws as 245i, that at the moment are not paying any
fees towards the USCIS. These people are waiting for a bill to pass or laws to be
made that would benefit them. They are awaiting the opportunity to pay USCIS
money in order to make their lives better. Not only increase the fees, but increase
the opportunities for people to pay those fees.

I finally voted last November. I hope it was worth the $520 I paid for that "right".

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Izabelle Gomes
